  1  1    Section 1.  Section 29C.1, subsection 3, Code 2016, is
  1  2 amended to read as follows:
  1  3    3.  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid among the
  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states
  1  1    Section 1.  Section 29C.1, subsection 3, Code 2016, is
  1  2 amended to read as follows:
  1  3    3.  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid among the
  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states  1  1    Section 1.  Section 29C.1, subsection 3, Code 2016, is
  1  2 amended to read as follows:
  1  3    3.  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid among the
  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states  1  2 amended to read as follows:
  1  3    3.  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid among the
  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states  1  3    3.  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid among the
  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states  1  4 political subdivisions of the state and with other states  1  5    1  6 the carrying out of emergency management functions  1  7 ensure the state government and its departments and agencies
  1  8 facilitate the rapid response of businesses and workers in the
  1  9 state and other states to a disaster  1  8 facilitate the rapid response of businesses and workers in the
  1  9 state and other states to a disaster  1  9 state and other states to a disaster  1 10    Sec. 2.    1 11 response to state=declared disasters Act.
  1 12    1.  Title.  This section may be cited as the "Facilitating
  1 13 Business Rapid Response to State=Declared Disasters Act".
  1 14    2.  Definitions.  For purposes of this section, unless the
  1 15 context otherwise requires:
  1 16    a.  (1)  "Critical infrastructure" means real and personal
  1 17 property and equipment owned or used by any of the following
  1 18 networks or systems, including related support facilities,
  1 19 which network or system provides service to more than one
  1 20 customer or person:
  1 21    (a)  Communication and video networks.
  1 22    (b)  Electric generation, transmission, and distribution
  1 23 systems.
  1 24    (c)  Gas distribution systems.
  1 25    (d)  Water and wastewater pipeline systems.
  1 26    (2)  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is not limited
  1 27 to buildings, structures, offices, lines, poles, pipes, and
  1 28 equipment.
  1 29    b.  "Declared state disaster or emergency" means a disaster
  1 30 or emergency event that meets at least one of the following
  1 31 conditions:
  1 32    (1)  A disaster emergency proclamation has been issued by the
  1 33 governor pursuant to section 29C.6 in relation to the event.
  1 34    (2)  A presidential declaration of a major disaster has been
  1 35 issued in relation to the event.
  2  1    c.  "Disaster or emergency=related work" means repairing,
  2  2 renovating, installing, building, or rendering services
  2  3 or other business activities, that relate to critical
  2  4 infrastructure that has been damaged, impaired, or destroyed by
  2  5 a declared state disaster or emergency.
  2  6    d.  "Disaster response period" means, with respect to
  2  7 each declared state disaster or emergency, a period of time
  2  8 that begins ten calendar days prior to the day the governor
  2  9 proclaims a disaster emergency or the president declares a
  2 10 major disaster, whichever occurs first, and extends for a
  2 11 period of sixty calendar days after the end of the declared
  2 12 state disaster or emergency.
  2 13    e.  (1)  "Out=of=state business" means a business entity that
  2 14 meets all of the following requirements:
  2 15    (a)  The business entity is requested to perform disaster or
  2 16 emergency=related work in the state by a registered business or
  2 17 by the state or a political subdivision of the state.
  2 18    (b)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 19 business entity has no presence in the state and conducts no
  2 20 business in the state.
  2 21    (c)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 22 business entity had no registrations, tax filings, or nexus in
  2 23 the state for the tax year immediately preceding the year in
  2 24 which the relevant declared state disaster or emergency occurs.
  2 25    (2)  "Out=of=state business" may include a business entity
  2 26 that is affiliated with a registered business solely through
  2 27 common ownership.
  2 28    f.  "Out=of=state employee" means an employee who does
  2 29 not work in this state except to perform disaster or
  2 30 emergency=related work during a disaster response period.
  2 31    g.  "Registered business" means a business entity that is
  2 32 registered to do business in the state prior to the declared
  2 33 state disaster or emergency.
  2 34    3.  Business and employee status during disaster response
  2 35 period.
  3  1    a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  3  2 contrary, an out=of=state business that conducts operations
  3  3 within the state solely for the purpose of performing disaster
  3  4 or emergency=related work during a disaster response period
  3  5 shall not be considered to have established a level of presence
  3  6 that would subject the out=of=state business to any of the
  3  7 following:
  3  8    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  3  9 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  3 10 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  3 11 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  3 12 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  3 13 state or a political subdivision.  This subparagraph (1) does
  3 14 not apply to the notification requirement in subsection 5.
  3 15    (2)  (a)  The requirement to collect and remit any tax
  3 16 imposed upon another person or file any related tax return or
  3 17 obtain any related tax permit.  This subparagraph division (a)
  3 18 does not apply to an out=of=state business for the collection
  3 19 and remittance of sales and use taxes under chapter 423 if the
  3 20 out=of=state business is registered voluntarily as a seller
  3 21 under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
  3 22    (b)  Subparagraph division (a) shall not be construed to
  3 23 protect or otherwise exempt any person liable for the payment
  3 24 of a tax, other than the out=of=state business, from the
  3 25 responsibility to pay such tax.
  3 26    (3)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  3 27 divisions II and III, including the requirement to file tax
  3 28 returns under sections 422.13 through 422.15 or 422.36, as
  3 29 applicable, and including the requirement to withhold and remit
  3 30 income tax from out=of=state employees under section 422.16.
  3 31 In addition, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  3 32 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  3 33 business or out=of=state employee shall not require an
  3 34 out=of=state business to be included in a consolidated return
  3 35 under section 422.37, and shall not increase the amount of net
  4  1 income of the out=of=state business allocated and apportioned
  4  2 to the state under sections 422.8 or 422.33, as applicable.
  4  3    (4)  The employment security requirements under chapter
  4  4 96, including but not limited to the payment of employer
  4  5 contributions under section 96.7.
  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.
  6 29    Sec. 3.  Section 422.8, subsection 2, paragraph a, Code 2016,
  6 30 is amended to read as follows:
  6 31    a.  Nonresident's net income allocated to Iowa is the net
  6 32 income, or portion of net income, which is derived from a
  6 33 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  6 34 this state or income from any property, trust, estate, or
  6 35 other source within Iowa. However, income derived from a
  7  1 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  7  2 this state and income from any property, trust, estate, or
  7  3 other source within Iowa shall not include distributions from
  7  4 pensions, including defined benefit or defined contribution
  7  5 plans, annuities, individual retirement accounts, and deferred
  7  6 compensation plans or any earnings attributable thereto so long
  7  7 as the distribution is directly related to an individual's
  7  8 documented retirement and received while the individual is a
  7  9 nonresident of this state. If a business, trade, profession,
  7 10 or occupation is carried on partly within and partly without
  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly
  7 12 and equitably attributable to that part of the business, trade,
  7 13 profession, or occupation carried on within the state is
  7 14 allocated to Iowa for purposes of section 422.5, subsection 1,
  7 15 paragraph "j", and section 422.13 and income from any property,
  7 16 trust, estate, or other source partly within and partly without
  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that
  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,
  7 21 profession, or occupation carried on within the state.   1 12    1.  Title.  This section may be cited as the "Facilitating

  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  6 31    a.  Nonresident's net income allocated to Iowa is the net

  6 34 this state or income from any property, trust, estate, or

  7  1 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  7  2 this state and income from any property, trust, estate, or

  7  4 pensions, including defined benefit or defined contribution
  7  5 plans, annuities, individual retirement accounts, and deferred
  7  6 compensation plans or any earnings attributable thereto so long
  7  7 as the distribution is directly related to an individual's
  7  8 documented retirement and received while the individual is a

  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly

  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that

  1 14    2.  Definitions.  For purposes of this section, unless the
  1 15 context otherwise requires:
  1 16    a.  (1)  "Critical infrastructure" means real and personal
  1 17 property and equipment owned or used by any of the following
  1 18 networks or systems, including related support facilities,
  1 19 which network or system provides service to more than one
  1 20 customer or person:
  1 21    (a)  Communication and video networks.
  1 22    (b)  Electric generation, transmission, and distribution
  1 23 systems.
  1 24    (c)  Gas distribution systems.
  1 25    (d)  Water and wastewater pipeline systems.
  1 26    (2)  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is not limited
  1 27 to buildings, structures, offices, lines, poles, pipes, and
  1 28 equipment.
  1 29    b.  "Declared state disaster or emergency" means a disaster
  1 30 or emergency event that meets at least one of the following
  1 31 conditions:
  1 32    (1)  A disaster emergency proclamation has been issued by the
  1 33 governor pursuant to section 29C.6 in relation to the event.
  1 34    (2)  A presidential declaration of a major disaster has been
  1 35 issued in relation to the event.
  2  1    c.  "Disaster or emergency=related work" means repairing,
  2  2 renovating, installing, building, or rendering services
  2  3 or other business activities, that relate to critical
  2  4 infrastructure that has been damaged, impaired, or destroyed by
  2  5 a declared state disaster or emergency.
  2  6    d.  "Disaster response period" means, with respect to
  2  7 each declared state disaster or emergency, a period of time
  2  8 that begins ten calendar days prior to the day the governor
  2  9 proclaims a disaster emergency or the president declares a
  2 10 major disaster, whichever occurs first, and extends for a
  2 11 period of sixty calendar days after the end of the declared
  2 12 state disaster or emergency.
  2 13    e.  (1)  "Out=of=state business" means a business entity that
  2 14 meets all of the following requirements:
  2 15    (a)  The business entity is requested to perform disaster or
  2 16 emergency=related work in the state by a registered business or
  2 17 by the state or a political subdivision of the state.
  2 18    (b)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 19 business entity has no presence in the state and conducts no
  2 20 business in the state.
  2 21    (c)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 22 business entity had no registrations, tax filings, or nexus in
  2 23 the state for the tax year immediately preceding the year in
  2 24 which the relevant declared state disaster or emergency occurs.
  2 25    (2)  "Out=of=state business" may include a business entity
  2 26 that is affiliated with a registered business solely through
  2 27 common ownership.
  2 28    f.  "Out=of=state employee" means an employee who does
  2 29 not work in this state except to perform disaster or
  2 30 emergency=related work during a disaster response period.
  2 31    g.  "Registered business" means a business entity that is
  2 32 registered to do business in the state prior to the declared
  2 33 state disaster or emergency.
  2 34    3.  Business and employee status during disaster response
  2 35 period.
  3  1    a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  3  2 contrary, an out=of=state business that conducts operations
  3  3 within the state solely for the purpose of performing disaster
  3  4 or emergency=related work during a disaster response period
  3  5 shall not be considered to have established a level of presence
  3  6 that would subject the out=of=state business to any of the
  3  7 following:
  3  8    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  3  9 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition

  3 12 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  3 13 state or a political subdivision.  This subparagraph (1) does
  3 14 not apply to the notification requirement in subsection 5.

  3 17 obtain any related tax permit.  This subparagraph division (a)
  3 18 does not apply to an out=of=state business for the collection
  3 19 and remittance of sales and use taxes under chapter 423 if the
  3 20 out=of=state business is registered voluntarily as a seller

  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  3 34 out=of=state business to be included in a consolidated return

  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.

  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.

  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the

  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee

  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee

  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing

  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,

  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.

  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.

  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other

  2  6    d.  "Disaster response period" means, with respect to
  2  7 each declared state disaster or emergency, a period of time
  2  8 that begins ten calendar days prior to the day the governor
  2  9 proclaims a disaster emergency or the president declares a
  2 10 major disaster, whichever occurs first, and extends for a
  2 11 period of sixty calendar days after the end of the declared
  2 12 state disaster or emergency.
  2 13    e.  (1)  "Out=of=state business" means a business entity that
  2 14 meets all of the following requirements:
  2 15    (a)  The business entity is requested to perform disaster or
  2 16 emergency=related work in the state by a registered business or
  2 17 by the state or a political subdivision of the state.
  2 18    (b)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 19 business entity has no presence in the state and conducts no
  2 20 business in the state.
  2 21    (c)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 22 business entity had no registrations, tax filings, or nexus in
  2 23 the state for the tax year immediately preceding the year in
  2 24 which the relevant declared state disaster or emergency occurs.
  2 25    (2)  "Out=of=state business" may include a business entity
  2 26 that is affiliated with a registered business solely through
  2 27 common ownership.
  2 28    f.  "Out=of=state employee" means an employee who does
  2 29 not work in this state except to perform disaster or
  2 30 emergency=related work during a disaster response period.
  2 31    g.  "Registered business" means a business entity that is
  2 32 registered to do business in the state prior to the declared
  2 33 state disaster or emergency.
  2 34    3.  Business and employee status during disaster response
  2 35 period.
  3  1    a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  3  2 contrary, an out=of=state business that conducts operations
  3  3 within the state solely for the purpose of performing disaster
  3  4 or emergency=related work during a disaster response period
  3  5 shall not be considered to have established a level of presence
  3  6 that would subject the out=of=state business to any of the
  3  7 following:
  3  8    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  3  9 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  3 10 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  3 11 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  3 12 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  3 13 state or a political subdivision.  This subparagraph (1) does
  3 14 not apply to the notification requirement in subsection 5.
  3 15    (2)  (a)  The requirement to collect and remit any tax
  3 16 imposed upon another person or file any related tax return or
  3 17 obtain any related tax permit.  This subparagraph division (a)
  3 18 does not apply to an out=of=state business for the collection
  3 19 and remittance of sales and use taxes under chapter 423 if the
  3 20 out=of=state business is registered voluntarily as a seller
  3 21 under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
  3 22    (b)  Subparagraph division (a) shall not be construed to
  3 23 protect or otherwise exempt any person liable for the payment
  3 24 of a tax, other than the out=of=state business, from the
  3 25 responsibility to pay such tax.
  3 26    (3)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  3 27 divisions II and III, including the requirement to file tax
  3 28 returns under sections 422.13 through 422.15 or 422.36, as
  3 29 applicable, and including the requirement to withhold and remit
  3 30 income tax from out=of=state employees under section 422.16.
  3 31 In addition, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  3 32 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  3 33 business or out=of=state employee shall not require an
  3 34 out=of=state business to be included in a consolidated return
  3 35 under section 422.37, and shall not increase the amount of net
  4  1 income of the out=of=state business allocated and apportioned
  4  2 to the state under sections 422.8 or 422.33, as applicable.
  4  3    (4)  The employment security requirements under chapter
  4  4 96, including but not limited to the payment of employer
  4  5 contributions under section 96.7.
  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  3 35 under section 422.37, and shall not increase the amount of net
  4  1 income of the out=of=state business allocated and apportioned
  4  2 to the state under sections 422.8 or 422.33, as applicable.
  4  3    (4)  The employment security requirements under chapter
  4  4 96, including but not limited to the payment of employer
  4  5 contributions under section 96.7.
  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state

  2  2 renovating, installing, building, or rendering services
  2  3 or other business activities, that relate to critical
  2  4 infrastructure that has been damaged, impaired, or destroyed by
  2  5 a declared state disaster or emergency.
  2  6    d.  "Disaster response period" means, with respect to
  2  7 each declared state disaster or emergency, a period of time
  2  8 that begins ten calendar days prior to the day the governor
  2  9 proclaims a disaster emergency or the president declares a
  2 10 major disaster, whichever occurs first, and extends for a
  2 11 period of sixty calendar days after the end of the declared
  2 12 state disaster or emergency.
  2 13    e.  (1)  "Out=of=state business" means a business entity that
  2 14 meets all of the following requirements:
  2 15    (a)  The business entity is requested to perform disaster or
  2 16 emergency=related work in the state by a registered business or
  2 17 by the state or a political subdivision of the state.
  2 18    (b)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 19 business entity has no presence in the state and conducts no
  2 20 business in the state.
  2 21    (c)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 22 business entity had no registrations, tax filings, or nexus in
  2 23 the state for the tax year immediately preceding the year in
  2 24 which the relevant declared state disaster or emergency occurs.
  2 25    (2)  "Out=of=state business" may include a business entity
  2 26 that is affiliated with a registered business solely through
  2 27 common ownership.
  2 28    f.  "Out=of=state employee" means an employee who does
  2 29 not work in this state except to perform disaster or
  2 30 emergency=related work during a disaster response period.
  2 31    g.  "Registered business" means a business entity that is
  2 32 registered to do business in the state prior to the declared
  2 33 state disaster or emergency.
  2 34    3.  Business and employee status during disaster response
  2 35 period.
  3  1    a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  3  2 contrary, an out=of=state business that conducts operations
  3  3 within the state solely for the purpose of performing disaster
  3  4 or emergency=related work during a disaster response period
  3  5 shall not be considered to have established a level of presence
  3  6 that would subject the out=of=state business to any of the
  3  7 following:
  3  8    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  3  9 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  3 10 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  3 11 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  3 12 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  3 13 state or a political subdivision.  This subparagraph (1) does
  3 14 not apply to the notification requirement in subsection 5.
  3 15    (2)  (a)  The requirement to collect and remit any tax
  3 16 imposed upon another person or file any related tax return or
  3 17 obtain any related tax permit.  This subparagraph division (a)
  3 18 does not apply to an out=of=state business for the collection
  3 19 and remittance of sales and use taxes under chapter 423 if the
  3 20 out=of=state business is registered voluntarily as a seller
  3 21 under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
  3 22    (b)  Subparagraph division (a) shall not be construed to
  3 23 protect or otherwise exempt any person liable for the payment
  3 24 of a tax, other than the out=of=state business, from the
  3 25 responsibility to pay such tax.
  3 26    (3)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  3 27 divisions II and III, including the requirement to file tax
  3 28 returns under sections 422.13 through 422.15 or 422.36, as
  3 29 applicable, and including the requirement to withhold and remit
  3 30 income tax from out=of=state employees under section 422.16.
  3 31 In addition, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  3 32 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  3 33 business or out=of=state employee shall not require an
  3 34 out=of=state business to be included in a consolidated return
  3 35 under section 422.37, and shall not increase the amount of net
  4  1 income of the out=of=state business allocated and apportioned
  4  2 to the state under sections 422.8 or 422.33, as applicable.
  4  3    (4)  The employment security requirements under chapter
  4  4 96, including but not limited to the payment of employer
  4  5 contributions under section 96.7.
  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.
  6 29    Sec. 3.  Section 422.8, subsection 2, paragraph a, Code 2016,
  6 30 is amended to read as follows:
  6 31    a.  Nonresident's net income allocated to Iowa is the net
  6 32 income, or portion of net income, which is derived from a
  6 33 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  6 34 this state or income from any property, trust, estate, or
  6 35 other source within Iowa. However, income derived from a
  7  1 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  7  2 this state and income from any property, trust, estate, or
  7  3 other source within Iowa shall not include distributions from
  7  4 pensions, including defined benefit or defined contribution
  7  5 plans, annuities, individual retirement accounts, and deferred
  7  6 compensation plans or any earnings attributable thereto so long
  7  7 as the distribution is directly related to an individual's
  7  8 documented retirement and received while the individual is a
  7  9 nonresident of this state. If a business, trade, profession,
  7 10 or occupation is carried on partly within and partly without
  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly
  7 12 and equitably attributable to that part of the business, trade,
  7 13 profession, or occupation carried on within the state is
  7 14 allocated to Iowa for purposes of section 422.5, subsection 1,
  7 15 paragraph "j", and section 422.13 and income from any property,
  7 16 trust, estate, or other source partly within and partly without
  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that
  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,
  7 21 profession, or occupation carried on within the state.   1 29    b.  "Declared state disaster or emergency" means a disaster

  1 31 conditions:
  1 32    (1)  A disaster emergency proclamation has been issued by the
  1 33 governor pursuant to section 29C.6 in relation to the event.
  1 34    (2)  A presidential declaration of a major disaster has been
  1 35 issued in relation to the event.
  2  1    c.  "Disaster or emergency=related work" means repairing,
  2  2 renovating, installing, building, or rendering services
  2  3 or other business activities, that relate to critical
  2  4 infrastructure that has been damaged, impaired, or destroyed by
  2  5 a declared state disaster or emergency.
  2  6    d.  "Disaster response period" means, with respect to
  2  7 each declared state disaster or emergency, a period of time
  2  8 that begins ten calendar days prior to the day the governor
  2  9 proclaims a disaster emergency or the president declares a
  2 10 major disaster, whichever occurs first, and extends for a
  2 11 period of sixty calendar days after the end of the declared
  2 12 state disaster or emergency.
  2 13    e.  (1)  "Out=of=state business" means a business entity that
  2 14 meets all of the following requirements:
  2 15    (a)  The business entity is requested to perform disaster or
  2 16 emergency=related work in the state by a registered business or
  2 17 by the state or a political subdivision of the state.
  2 18    (b)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 19 business entity has no presence in the state and conducts no
  2 20 business in the state.
  2 21    (c)  Except for disaster and emergency=related work, the
  2 22 business entity had no registrations, tax filings, or nexus in
  2 23 the state for the tax year immediately preceding the year in
  2 24 which the relevant declared state disaster or emergency occurs.
  2 25    (2)  "Out=of=state business" may include a business entity
  2 26 that is affiliated with a registered business solely through
  2 27 common ownership.

  2 30 emergency=related work during a disaster response period.

  2 32 registered to do business in the state prior to the declared
  2 33 state disaster or emergency.

  2 35 period.
  3  1    a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  3  2 contrary, an out=of=state business that conducts operations
  3  3 within the state solely for the purpose of performing disaster
  3  4 or emergency=related work during a disaster response period
  3  5 shall not be considered to have established a level of presence
  3  6 that would subject the out=of=state business to any of the
  3  7 following:
  3  8    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  3  9 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  3 10 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  3 11 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  3 12 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  3 13 state or a political subdivision.  This subparagraph (1) does
  3 14 not apply to the notification requirement in subsection 5.
  3 15    (2)  (a)  The requirement to collect and remit any tax
  3 16 imposed upon another person or file any related tax return or
  3 17 obtain any related tax permit.  This subparagraph division (a)
  3 18 does not apply to an out=of=state business for the collection
  3 19 and remittance of sales and use taxes under chapter 423 if the
  3 20 out=of=state business is registered voluntarily as a seller
  3 21 under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
  3 22    (b)  Subparagraph division (a) shall not be construed to
  3 23 protect or otherwise exempt any person liable for the payment
  3 24 of a tax, other than the out=of=state business, from the
  3 25 responsibility to pay such tax.
  3 26    (3)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  3 27 divisions II and III, including the requirement to file tax
  3 28 returns under sections 422.13 through 422.15 or 422.36, as
  3 29 applicable, and including the requirement to withhold and remit
  3 30 income tax from out=of=state employees under section 422.16.
  3 31 In addition, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  3 32 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  3 33 business or out=of=state employee shall not require an
  3 34 out=of=state business to be included in a consolidated return
  3 35 under section 422.37, and shall not increase the amount of net
  4  1 income of the out=of=state business allocated and apportioned
  4  2 to the state under sections 422.8 or 422.33, as applicable.
  4  3    (4)  The employment security requirements under chapter
  4  4 96, including but not limited to the payment of employer
  4  5 contributions under section 96.7.
  4  6    (5)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or
  4  7 the equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal
  4  8 property or equipment purchased outside the state and brought
  4  9 into the state to aid in the performance of disaster or
  4 10 emergency=related work during a disaster response period if
  4 11 such tangible personal property or equipment does not remain in
  4 12 the state after the conclusion of the disaster response period.
  4 13    (6)  The assessment of property taxes by the department
  4 14 of revenue under sections 428.24 through 428.26, 428.28, and
  4 15 428.29, or chapters 433, 434, 435, and 437 through 438, or by
  4 16 a local assessor under another provision of law, on property
  4 17 brought into the state to aid in the performance of disaster
  4 18 or emergency=related work during a disaster period if such
  4 19 property does not remain in the state after the conclusion of
  4 20 the disaster response period.
  4 21    b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  4 22 contrary, the performance of disaster or emergency=related
  4 23 work during a disaster response period by an out=of=state
  4 24 employee shall not be used as the basis to determine that the
  4 25 out=of=state employee has established residency or a level of
  4 26 presence that would subject the out=of=state employee to any
  4 27 of the following:
  4 28    (1)  The requirement to complete or obtain any state or local
  4 29 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
  4 30 of doing business in this state or engaging in an occupation
  4 31 in this state, or to pay any related fee, including but not
  4 32 limited to the requirement to register with the secretary of
  4 33 state or a political subdivision.
  4 34    (2)  The imposition of income taxes under chapter 422,
  4 35 division II, including the requirement to file tax returns
  5  1 under section 422.13 and the requirement to be subject to
  5  2 withholding of income tax under section 422.16.  In addition,
  5  3 the performance of disaster or emergency=related work during a
  5  4 disaster response period by an out=of=state employee shall not
  5  5 increase the amount of net income of the out=of=state employee
  5  6 allocated and apportioned to the state under section 422.8.
  5  7    (3)  The use tax under chapter 423, subchapter III, or the
  5  8 equipment tax under chapter 423D, on tangible personal property
  5  9 or equipment purchased outside the state and used in the state
  5 10 to aid in the performance of disaster or emergency=related work
  5 11 during a disaster response period if such tangible personal
  5 12 property or equipment does not remain in the state after the
  5 13 conclusion of the disaster response period.
  5 14    c.  During a disaster response period, an out=of=state
  5 15 business or an out=of=state employee shall be subject to all
  5 16 taxes and fees not included in paragraphs "a" and "b", and this
  5 17 subsection shall not be construed to provide protection or
  5 18 exemption during a disaster response period or any other period
  5 19 from taxes or taxable events not included in paragraphs "a" and
  5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
