  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.
  6 29    Sec. 3.  Section 422.8, subsection 2, paragraph a, Code 2016,
  6 30 is amended to read as follows:
  6 31    a.  Nonresident's net income allocated to Iowa is the net
  6 32 income, or portion of net income, which is derived from a
  6 33 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  6 34 this state or income from any property, trust, estate, or
  6 35 other source within Iowa. However, income derived from a
  7  1 business, trade, profession, or occupation carried on within
  7  2 this state and income from any property, trust, estate, or
  7  3 other source within Iowa shall not include distributions from
  7  4 pensions, including defined benefit or defined contribution
  7  5 plans, annuities, individual retirement accounts, and deferred
  7  6 compensation plans or any earnings attributable thereto so long
  7  7 as the distribution is directly related to an individual's
  7  8 documented retirement and received while the individual is a
  7  9 nonresident of this state. If a business, trade, profession,
  7 10 or occupation is carried on partly within and partly without
  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly
  7 12 and equitably attributable to that part of the business, trade,
  7 13 profession, or occupation carried on within the state is
  7 14 allocated to Iowa for purposes of section 422.5, subsection 1,
  7 15 paragraph "j", and section 422.13 and income from any property,
  7 16 trust, estate, or other source partly within and partly without
  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that
  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,

  5 20 "b".

  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,
  7 21 profession, or occupation carried on within the state.   5 20 "b".
  5 21    4.  Business and employee status after a disaster response
  5 22 period.  An out=of=state business or out=of=state employee
  5 23 that remains in the state after the conclusion of the disaster
  5 24 response period for which the disaster or emergency=related
  5 25 work was performed shall be fully subject to the state's
  5 26 standards for establishing presence, residency, or doing
  5 27 business as otherwise provided by law, and shall be responsible
  5 28 for any resulting taxes, fees, licensing, registration, filing,
  5 29 or other requirements.
  5 30    5.  Notification of out=of=state business during disaster
  5 31 response period.
  5 32    a.  An out=of=state business that enters the state to perform
  5 33 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
  5 34 period shall provide notification to the secretary of state,
  5 35 which notification shall contain all the following information
  6  1 related to the out=of=state business:
  6  2    (1)  Name.
  6  3    (2)  State of domicile.
  6  4    (3)  Principal business address.
  6  5    (4)  Federal employer identification number.
  6  6    (5)  The date the out=of=state business entered the state.
  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  6  7    (6)  Contact information.
  6  8    (7)  A statement that the out=of=state business is in
  6  9 the state for the purpose of responding to a declared state
  6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.

  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly
  7 12 and equitably attributable to that part of the business, trade,
  7 13 profession, or occupation carried on within the state is
  7 14 allocated to Iowa for purposes of section 422.5, subsection 1,
  7 15 paragraph "j", and section 422.13 and income from any property,
  7 16 trust, estate, or other source partly within and partly without
  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that
  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,
  7 21 profession, or occupation carried on within the state.   6 10 disaster or emergency.
  6 11    b.  For an out=of=state business that enters this state to
  6 12 perform disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster
  6 13 response period as an affiliate of a registered business, the
  6 14 registered business shall provide, on behalf of the affiliate
  6 15 out=of=state business, the notification required in paragraph
  6 16 "a", which notification shall also include contact information
  6 17 for the registered business.
  6 18    c.  The secretary of state shall transmit notification
  6 19 information to the department, department of revenue, and other
  6 20 appropriate state and local government agencies and officials.
  6 21    6.  Powers and duties not created.  This Act shall not be
  6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  7  5 plans, annuities, individual retirement accounts, and deferred
  7  6 compensation plans or any earnings attributable thereto so long
  7  7 as the distribution is directly related to an individual's
  7  8 documented retirement and received while the individual is a
  7  9 nonresident of this state. If a business, trade, profession,
  7 10 or occupation is carried on partly within and partly without
  7 11 the state, only the portion of the net income which is fairly
  7 12 and equitably attributable to that part of the business, trade,
  7 13 profession, or occupation carried on within the state is
  7 14 allocated to Iowa for purposes of section 422.5, subsection 1,
  7 15 paragraph "j", and section 422.13 and income from any property,
  7 16 trust, estate, or other source partly within and partly without
  7 17 the state is allocated to Iowa in the same manner, except that
  7 18 annuities, interest on bank deposits and interest=bearing
  7 19 obligations, and dividends are allocated to Iowa only to the
  7 20 extent to which they are derived from a business, trade,
  7 21 profession, or occupation carried on within the state.   6 22 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
  6 23 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
  6 24 power for a local emergency management commission not already
  6 25 expressly granted in another provision of this chapter.
  6 26    7.  Rules.  The department, the secretary of state, and
  6 27 the department of revenue shall each adopt rules pursuant to
  6 28 chapter 17A to jointly administer this section.

  9 35                           EXPLANATION
 10  1 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 10  2 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 10  3    This bill establishes the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 10  4 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" and provides
 10  5 definitions. The bill also amends the statement of policy in
 10  6 Code chapter 29C (Emergency Management and Security).
 10  7    The bill provides that notwithstanding any law to the
 10  8 contrary, an out=of=state business or an out=of=state employee
 10  9 that performs disaster and emergency=related work during a
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
  9 23 subparagraph (6).
  9 24    Sec. 14.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This Act, being deemed
  9 25 of immediate importance, takes effect upon enactment.
  9 26    Sec. 15.  RETROACTIVE APPLICABILITY.  The following
  9 27 provision or provisions of this Act apply retroactively to
  9 28 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date:
  9 29    1.  The section of this Act amending section 422.8.
  9 30    2.  The section of this Act amending section 422.13.
  9 31    3.  The section of this Act amending section 422.16.
  9 32    4.  The section of this Act amending section 422.33.
  9 33    5.  The section of this Act amending section 422.36.
  9 34    6.  The section of this Act amending section 422.37.
  9 35                           EXPLANATION
 10  1 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 10  2 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 10  3    This bill establishes the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 10  4 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" and provides
 10  5 definitions. The bill also amends the statement of policy in
 10  6 Code chapter 29C (Emergency Management and Security).
 10  7    The bill provides that notwithstanding any law to the
 10  8 contrary, an out=of=state business or an out=of=state employee
 10  9 that performs disaster and emergency=related work during a
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc

 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
  9 27 provision or provisions of this Act apply retroactively to
  9 28 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date:
  9 29    1.  The section of this Act amending section 422.8.
  9 30    2.  The section of this Act amending section 422.13.
  9 31    3.  The section of this Act amending section 422.16.
  9 32    4.  The section of this Act amending section 422.33.
  9 33    5.  The section of this Act amending section 422.36.
  9 34    6.  The section of this Act amending section 422.37.
  9 35                           EXPLANATION
 10  1 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 10  2 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 10  3    This bill establishes the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 10  4 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" and provides
 10  5 definitions. The bill also amends the statement of policy in
 10  6 Code chapter 29C (Emergency Management and Security).
 10  7    The bill provides that notwithstanding any law to the
 10  8 contrary, an out=of=state business or an out=of=state employee
 10  9 that performs disaster and emergency=related work during a
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86

  9 31    3.  The section of this Act amending section 422.16.
  9 32    4.  The section of this Act amending section 422.33.
  9 33    5.  The section of this Act amending section 422.36.
  9 34    6.  The section of this Act amending section 422.37.
  9 35                           EXPLANATION
 10  1 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 10  2 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 10  3    This bill establishes the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 10  4 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" and provides
 10  5 definitions. The bill also amends the statement of policy in
 10  6 Code chapter 29C (Emergency Management and Security).
 10  7    The bill provides that notwithstanding any law to the
 10  8 contrary, an out=of=state business or an out=of=state employee
 10  9 that performs disaster and emergency=related work during a
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc

  9 33    5.  The section of this Act amending section 422.36.
  9 34    6.  The section of this Act amending section 422.37.

 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 10  5 definitions. The bill also amends the statement of policy in
 10  6 Code chapter 29C (Emergency Management and Security).
 10  7    The bill provides that notwithstanding any law to the
 10  8 contrary, an out=of=state business or an out=of=state employee
 10  9 that performs disaster and emergency=related work during a
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.

 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

       mm/sc
 10 10 disaster response period will be protected from, and shall not
 10 11 be subject to, certain taxes, fees, licensing, registration,
 10 12 filing, and other requirements, as specified in the bill.
 10 13    "Disaster response period" is defined as a period of time
 10 14 beginning 10 days before the governor proclaims a state
 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state

 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:

 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,

 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 10 15 disaster or emergency or the president declares a major
 10 16 disaster in the state, and ends 60 days after the end of
 10 17 the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Disaster and
 10 18 emergency=related work" is defined to include a variety of work
 10 19 on critical infrastructure damaged, impaired, or destroyed
 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.

 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
