 10 20 by the declared state disaster or emergency.  "Critical
 10 21 infrastructure" is defined to include property and equipment
 10 22 owned or used by a communication and video network; electric
 10 23 generation, transmission, and distribution system; gas
 10 24 distribution system; water and wastewater pipeline system;
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.

 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 10 25 or a related support facility of those networks or systems.
 10 26 The network or system must provide service to more than one
 10 27 customer or person.  "Critical infrastructure" includes but is
 10 28 not limited to buildings, structures,  offices, lines, poles,
 10 29 pipes, and equipment.
 10 30    OUT=OF=STATE BUSINESSES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.

 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 10 31 business" and provides that an out=of=state business performing
 10 32 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 10 33 period shall not be considered to have established a level of
 10 34 presence that would subject it to the following:
 10 35    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local business or
 11  1 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.

 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 11  2 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 11  3 or pay any related fee.
 11  4    2.  The requirement to collect and remit any tax imposed upon
 11  5 another person, or file any related tax return or obtain any
 11  6 related tax permit, except for the collection of sales and use
 11  7 tax by an out=of=state business registered voluntarily as a
 11  8 seller under the streamlined sales and use tax agreement.
 11  9    3.  The requirement to pay the individual or corporate
 11 10 income tax, including the requirement to file a tax return
 11 11 or be included in a consolidated tax return, withhold and
 11 12 remit income tax from out=of=state employees, or increase the
 11 13 amount of the out=of=state business's net income allocated
 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local

 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.

 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income

 11 14 and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster and
 11 15 emergency=related work.
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86

 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 11 16    4.  The requirement to be subject to the employment security
 11 17 requirements of Code chapter 96, including but not limited to
 11 18 the requirement to make employer contributions.
 11 19    5.  For tangible personal property and equipment purchased
 11 20 outside of Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the
 11 21 performance of disaster or emergency=related work, the
 11 22 requirement to pay use tax or  equipment tax on the property, or
 11 23 have the property assessed for property tax purposes, provided
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to

 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 11 24 the property does not remain in the state after the disaster
 11 25 response period.
 11 26    Out=of=state businesses that enter the state to perform
 11 27 disaster and emergency=related work during a disaster response
 11 28 period are required to provide a notification containing
 11 29 various information to the secretary of state.  If the
 11 30 out=of=state business enters the state as an affiliate of a
 11 31 registered business, the registered business must provide the
 11 32 required notification on behalf of the out=of=state business.
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.

 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
       LSB 5105HV (2) 86
       mm/sc
 11 33 "Registered business" is defined in the bill.  The secretary of
 11 34 state is required to share the notification information with
 11 35 various state and local agencies and officials as specified in
 12  1 the bill.
 12  2    OUT=OF=STATE EMPLOYEES.  The bill defines "out=of=state
 12  3 employee" and provides that the performance of disaster or
 12  4 emergency=related work during a disaster response period by
 12  5 an out=of=state employee shall not be used as the basis to
 12  6 determine the out=of=state employee has established residency
 12  7 or a level of presence that would subject the out=of=state
 12  8 employee to the following:
 12  9    1.  The requirement to obtain any state or local
 12 10 registration, license, or similar authorization as a condition
 12 11 of doing business or engaging in an occupation in this state,
 12 12 or pay any related fee.
 12 13    2.  The requirement to pay the individual income tax or
 12 14 file a tax return, be subject to income tax withholding, or
 12 15 increase the amount of the out=of=state employee's net income
 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 12 16 allocated and apportioned to Iowa as a result of the disaster
 12 17 and emergency=related work.
 12 18    3.  The requirement to pay use tax or equipment tax on
 12 19 tangible personal property and equipment purchased outside of
 12 20 Iowa and brought into the state to aid in the performance of
 12 21 disaster or emergency=related work, provided the property does
 12 22 not remain in the state after the disaster response period.
 12 23    The bill provides that out=of=state businesses and
 12 24 out=of=state employees shall be subject to all taxes and fees
 12 25 not specifically included in the bill, and provides that
 12 26 out=of=state businesses and out=of=state employees that remain
 12 27 in Iowa after the conclusion of the disaster response period
 12 28 shall be fully subject to Iowa's standards for establishing
 12 29 presence, residency, or doing business as otherwise provided by
 12 30 law, and shall be responsible for any resulting taxes, fees,
 12 31 licensing, registration, filing, or other requirements.
 12 32    The bill includes cross references to the tax exclusions
 12 33 and exemptions created in the bill in several sections of the
 12 34 Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax (Code
 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.

 12 35 chapter 422), the sales and use tax (Code chapter 423), the
 13  1 equipment tax (Code chapter 423D), and the property tax (Code
 13  2 chapter 427).  The cross references to the individual and
 13  3 corporate income tax in Code chapter 422 are retroactive to
 13  4 January 1, 2016, for tax years beginning on or after that date.
 13  5    The bill provides that the "Facilitating Business Rapid
 13  6 Response to State=Declared Disasters Act" shall not be
 13  7 construed to place any new mandates or duties upon a local
 13  8 emergency management commission or create any new authority or
 13  9 power for a local emergency management commission not already
 13 10 expressly provided in another provision of Code chapter 29C
 13 11 (Emergency Management and Security).
 13 12    The bill takes effect upon enactment.
